sen.j: 飛鳥文化（あすかぶんか）は、推古天皇を頂点として大和国を中心に華開いた仏教文化である。
sen.e: Asuka Bunka (Asuka Culture) is a culture that florished mainly in Yamato Province under the reign of Emperor Suiko at a peak.
Asuka Culture was a culture that flourished mainly in Yamato Province under Empress Suiko.
Asuka Culture was a Buddhist culture that flourished mainly in Yamato Province under Empress Suiko.

sen.j: 時期としては、一般に仏教渡来から大化の改新までをいう。
sen.e: It generally covers the era from the introduction of Buddhism in Japan upto Taika no Kaishin (the Great Reformation of the Taika Era).
It generally covers the era from the introduction of Buddhism in Japan through the Taika Reforms.
It generally covers the era from the introduction of Buddhism in Japan through the Taika Reforms.

sen.j: 朝鮮半島の百済や高句麗を通じて伝えられた中国大陸の南北朝時代 (中国)の文化の影響を受け、国際性豊かな文化でもある。
sen.e: It was a substantially international culture being influenced by the culture of Chinese continent in the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties, which was transferred to Japan through Kudara (Baekje or Paekche) and Koguryo (Goguryeu) in the Korean Peninsula.

It was an abundantly cosmopolitan culture, influenced by the Northern and Southern Dynasties period culture of the Chinese continent, which was introduced to Japan via the Korean kingdoms of Baekje and Goguryeo.

It was an abundantly cosmopolitan culture, influenced by the Northern and Southern Dynasties period culture of the Chinese continent, which was introduced to Japan via the Korean kingdoms of Baekje and Goguryeo.

sen.j: 多くの大寺院が建立され始め、仏教文化の最初の興隆期であった。
sen.e: It was the first prosperous period of Buddhist culture, with numbers of large temples under construction.
It was the first prosperous period of Buddhist culture and saw the construction of many large temples.
It was the first prosperous period of Buddhist culture and saw the construction of many large temples.

tit.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 仏教の百済からの公伝は宣化天皇・欽明天皇の538年（宣化3）または552年（欽明13）といわれている。
sen.e: An official introduction of Buddhism from Kudara (Baekje or Paekche) to Japan was reportedly made in 538 or 552, under the reign of Emperor Senka or Emperor Kinmei, respectively.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Buddhism was officially introduced into Japan via Baekje either during the reign of Emperor Senka in 538 or the reign of Emperor Kinmei in 552..
Buddhism was officially introduced into Japan via Baekje either during the reign of Emperor Senka in 538 or the reign of Emperor Kinmei in 552.
sen.cmt: ピリオド削除しました。

sen.j: 当時仏教受容の先頭を切ったのは蘇我稲目であり、百済の聖王が日本の朝廷の伝えてきた金銅釈迦像・経典若干卷のうちの仏像を小墾田（おはりだ）の家に安置し、さらに向原（むくはら）の家を清めて向原寺（こうげんじ）とした（『日本書紀』）。
sen.e: SOGA no Iname was the person who spearheaded to take Buddhism in Japan, by enshrining a gilt bronze statue of Shakyamuni and certain rolls of Buddhist sutra, which joo (seong-wang or holy-king) of Kudara presented to Imperial court of Japan, in the house of Oharida and by purifying his house in Mukuhara to convert it into Kogen-ji Temple, according to "Nihonshoki" ("The Chronicle of Japan").
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), the introduction of Buddhism into Japan was spearheaded by SOGA no Iname, who enshrined a gilt bronze statue of Shakyamuni that had been presented, together with some sutras, to the Imperial court by King Seong of Baekje, in his house at Oharida and purified his house in Mukuhara, converting it into Kogen-ji Temple.

According to the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), the introduction of Buddhism into Japan was spearheaded by SOGA no Iname, who enshrined a gilt bronze statue of Shakyamuni that had been presented, together with some sutras, to the Imperial court by King Seong of Baekje, in his house at Oharida and purified his house in Mukuhara, converting it into Kogen-ji Temple.

sen.j: 仏教の摂取と流布に大いに貢献した蘇我氏とこれに反対する物部氏との対立（崇仏論争）はのちに蘇我馬子と物部守屋との間での戦乱を招く。
sen.e: Subutsu-ronso (dispute about worshipping Buddha) broke out between Soga clan who had greatly contributed to dissemination of Buddhism in Japan and its opponent Mononobe clan, which caused subsequent wars between SOGA no Umako and MONONOBE no Moriya.

A dispute over the adoption of Buddhism between the Soga Clan, who had greatly contributed to dissemination of Buddhism in Japan, and their opponents, the Mononobe Clan led to conflict between SOGA no Umako and MONONOBE no Moriya.

A dispute over the adoption of Buddhism between the Soga clan, who had greatly contributed to dissemination of Buddhism in Japan, and their opponents, the Mononobe clan led to conflict between SOGA no Umako and MONONOBE no Moriya.

sen.j: これに勝利した蘇我氏と蘇我氏系大王のもと、王権の本拠地である飛鳥京を中心に仏教文化が発展する。
sen.e: Soga clan won the wars, and developed Buddhist culture mainly in Asuka no Miyako (the capital of Asuka), home ground of Soga clan, under the sovereignty of Soga's affiliated okimi (a great king).

Following the Soga's victory, Buddhist culture developed under the Soga Clan and the clan-affiliated Okimi (King, a term used before "Emperor" became common), mainly in and around the capital Asuka-kyo, home to the Yamato royalty.
sen.cmt: *Although both Asuka no Miyako and Asuka-kyo are OK, I think the latter is preferable for consistency's sake eg Heian-kyo, Fujiwara-kyo, etc
sen.e: Following the Soga's victory, Buddhist culture developed under the Soga clan and the clan-affiliated Okimi (King, a term used before "Emperor" became common), mainly in and around the capital Asuka-kyo, home to the Yamato royalty.

sen.j: 飛鳥仏教は百済と高句麗の仏僧によって支えられていた。
sen.e: The Buddhism in Asuka capital was supported by monks from Kudara (Baekje or Paekche) and Kokuri (Goguryeo).
Buddhism in Asuka was supported by monks from Baekje and Goguryeo.
Buddhism in Asuka was supported by monks from Baekje and Goguryeo.

sen.j: 595年（推古3）に高句麗僧慧慈（えじ）・百済僧慧聰（えそう）が来朝・帰化した。
sen.e: In 595, Eji and Eso, monks from Kokuri (Goguryeo) and Kudara (Baekje or Paekche), respectively, arrived in Japan and naturalized themselves.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 595, two monks, Eji from Goguryeo and Eso from Baekje, arrived in Japan and became naturalized.
In 595, two monks, Eji from Goguryeo and Eso from Baekje, arrived in Japan and became naturalized.

sen.j: 翌年には飛鳥寺に住まうようになる。
sen.e: In the next year, they settled themselves in Asuka-dera Temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The next year, they began living in Asuka-dera Temple.
The next year, they began living in Asuka-dera Temple.

tit.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 飛鳥寺や四天王寺は、発願者の意図と違って国家的な寺院（官寺）であった。
sen.e: Differently from the real intension of devotees, Asuka-dera Temple and Shitenno-ji Temple became the temples under state-administration.
Contrary to the intentions of devotees, Asuka-dera Temple and Shitenno-ji Temple became state-administered temples.
Contrary to the intentions of devotees, Asuka-dera Temple and Shitenno-ji Temple became state-administered temples.

sen.j: 造寺・造仏の技術者は主として朝鮮からの渡来人やその子孫達であった。
sen.e: Engineers engaged in construction of Buddhist temples and statures in Japan were mainly settlers from Korea and their descendants.
Craftsmen engaged in the construction of Buddhist temples and statures in Japan were mainly settlers from Korea and their descendants.
Craftsmen engaged in the construction of Buddhist temples and statures in Japan were mainly settlers from Korea and their descendants.

sen.j: また、594年（推古2）に仏教興隆の詔が下されたのを受けて諸臣連達が、天皇と自己の祖先一族のために競って私寺（氏寺）を造り始めた。
sen.e: In 594, when an imperial decree to promote Buddhism was issued, ranks of retainers strived for building their private temples (uji-dera temples, or temples built for praying clan's glory) for ancestors of Emperor and themselves.
In 594, following the issue of an imperial decree promoting Buddhism, many powerful clans competed to build private temples (known as uji-dera) for to the Emperor and their ancestors.
In 594, following the issue of an imperial decree promoting Buddhism, many powerful clans competed to build private temples (known as uji-dera) for the Emperor and their ancestors.
sen.cmt: 余分な単語を削除しました。

sen.j: 四天王寺
sen.e: Shitenno-ji Temple:
Shitenno-ji Temple
Shitenno-ji Temple

sen.j: 難波(大阪)。
sen.e: Nanba or Naniwa (Osaka)
Naniwa (Osaka)
sen.cmt: *Although close to Nanba, I don't think the temple is actually in Nanba, so I think this refers to the old name of Osaka
sen.e: Naniwa (Osaka)

sen.j: 聖徳太子創建の日本で最初の本格的な官寺。
sen.e: This was founded by Prince Shotoku as the first fully-fledged state-sponsored temple in Japan.
This was founded by Prince Shotoku as the first fully-fledged state-sponsored temple in Japan.
This was founded by Prince Shotoku as the first fully-fledged state-sponsored temple in Japan.

sen.j: 法興寺（飛鳥寺、安居院）
sen.e: Hoko-ji Temple (Asuka-dera Temple, Ango-in):
Hoko-ji Temple (Asuka-dera Temple, Ango-in)
Hoko-ji Temple (Asuka-dera Temple, Ango-in)

sen.j: 崇峻朝の588年（崇峻元）に着工され、596年（推古4）に完成した。
sen.e: Commencement and completion of construction works of this temple was 588 under the reign of Emperor Sushun and 596 under the reign of Emperor Suiko, respectively.
Construction began in 588 during the reign of Emperor Sushun and was completed in 596 during the reign of Empress Suiko.
Construction began in 588 during the reign of Emperor Sushun and was completed in 596 during the reign of Empress Suiko.

sen.j: 蘇我馬子が造営の中心になった。
sen.e: The central figure in the construction works was SOGA no Umako.
The central figure in the construction was SOGA no Umako.
The central figure in the construction was SOGA no Umako.

sen.j: 寺司（てらのつかさ）は馬子の長子・善徳。
sen.e: Tera no tsukasa (the head official of the temple) was Zentoku, the eldest son of Umako.
The tera no tsukasa (head official of the temple) was Umako's eldest son, Zentoku.
The tera no tsukasa (head official of the temple) was Umako's eldest son, Zentoku.

sen.j: 日本で最初の本格的な私寺であるが、蘇我系王族の強い支援のもと、官寺としての性格が強い。
sen.e: Though it was the first full-scale private temple in Japan, Hoko-ji Temple had strong characteristics as of a state-owned temple being sponsored by royal families under the control of Soga clan.
Although it was the first full-scale private temple in Japan, it strongly resembled a state-owned temple due to the support it received from the Soga Clan-controlled royal family.
Although it was the first full-scale private temple in Japan, it strongly resembled a state-owned temple due to the support it received from the Soga clan-controlled royal family.

sen.j: 伽藍は、ほぼ南北に通る中軸線上に南から南門・中門・塔・金堂・講堂が一直線上に並んでいる四天王寺式である。
sen.e: This temple took a style of Shitenno-ji Temple, consisting the south gate, inner gate, tower, golden hall (main hall) and lecture hall, all aligned on a central axial line running direct north and south.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The temple's design resembled that of Shitenno-ji Temple, with the Nanmon (South Gate), Chumon (Central Gate), pagoda, kondo (main hall) and kodo (lecture hall) running in a straight line from south to north.

The temple's design resembled that of Shitenno-ji Temple, with the Nanmon (South Gate), Chumon (Central Gate), pagoda, kondo (main hall) and kodo (lecture hall) running in a straight line from south to north.

sen.j: 塔の東西にも金堂が置かれ、中門から出ている回廊はその外側を通って、金堂の背後で閉じている。
sen.e: It had additional two golden halls positioned at east and west of the tower, while a corridor from the inner gate was split to go around the outside of two golden halls and again converge behind the main hall.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It had two additional kondo situated to the east and west of the pagoda, with a corridor from the Chumon Gate that went around them and converged behind the kondo.
It had two additional kondo situated to the east and west of the pagoda, with a corridor from the Chumon Gate that went around them and converged behind the kondo.

sen.j: 現在の安居院は中金堂の位置にあり、鞍作止利作とされる金銅仏・飛鳥大仏が安置されている。
sen.e: At the same place as the main golden hall stood, there stands the current Ango-in Hall which houses Kondo-butsu or Asuka Daibutsu (a gilt bronze statue of Buddha in a sitting position) that is believed to have been made by KURATSUKURI no Tori.

The site of the main kondo is now occupied by the Ango-in Hall, which houses the Kondo-butsu or Asuka Daibutsu (a gilt bronze statue of Buddha in a sitting position), believed to have been made by KURATSUKURI no Tori.

The site of the main kondo is now occupied by the Ango-in Hall, which houses the Kondo-butsu or Asuka Daibutsu (a gilt bronze statue of Buddha in a sitting position), believed to have been made by KURATSUKURI no Tori.

sen.j: 593年（推古元）塔の心礎に仏舎利を安置したという（『日本書紀』）。
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki" ("The Chronicle of Japan"), Buddha's relics (ashes) were burried as the central base of pagoda in 593.
According to the "Nihonshoki", Buddha's ashes were buried under the central foundation stone of the pagoda in 593.
According to the "Nihonshoki," Buddha's ashes were buried under the central foundation stone of the pagoda in 593.
sen.cmt: カンマ位置移動しました。

sen.j: これ以後の皇居（宮）もほぼこの飛鳥寺を中心にした飛鳥に置かれた。
sen.e: Since then, most of imperial palaces were built in the Asuka area centering around this Asuka-dera Temple.
Following its construction, most imperial palaces were built in the Asuka area centered around Asuka-dera Temple.
Following its construction, most imperial palaces were built in the Asuka area centered around Asuka-dera Temple.

sen.j: 飛鳥寺の中軸線と天智天皇の末年か天武天皇初年に建てられた川原寺の中軸線との中心線（中道）は、天武朝の藤原京の設定の一基準となり、両中軸の間隔は亦、飛鳥の方格地割りの基準となった。
sen.e: A central line (middle road) in between the axial line of Asuka-dera Temple and that of Kawahara-dera Temple, which was built in the last year of Emperor Tenchi's reign or the first year of Emperor Tenmu's reign, became one of standards to design Fujiwara Capital under the reign of Emperor Tenmu, and the distance of both axial lines became a standard measurement of grid lines for allotment of Asuka land.

The central line (middle road) between Asuka-dera Temple's central axis and that of Kawahara-dera Temple, which was built in the last year of Emperor Tenchi's reign or the first year of Emperor Tenmu's reign, became one of standards in the design of Emperor Tenmu's capital, Fujiwara-kyo, and the distance between both axial lines became a standard measurement of grid lines for allotment of land in Asuka.

The central line (middle road) between Asuka-dera Temple's central axis and that of Kawahara-dera Temple, which was built in the last year of Emperor Tenchi's reign or the first year of Emperor Tenmu's reign, became one of standards in the design of Emperor Tenmu's capital, Fujiwara-kyo, and the distance between both axial lines became a standard measurement of grid lines for allotment of land in Asuka.

sen.j: 百済大寺
sen.e: Kudara-daiji Temple:
sen.cmt: 用語登録では「百済大寺」は"Kudara daiji Temple"とされています。
sen.e: Kudara-daiji Temple
Kudara-daiji Temple

sen.j: 舒明天皇の没後、妻の皇極天皇、子の天智によって継承され、639年（舒明11）に完成された天皇家最初の仏教寺院である。
sen.e: This was the first Buddhist temple of Imperial families, completed in 639 by Emperor Jomei and, after his death, succeeded by his consort Empress Kogyoku and his son Empreror Tenchi.
This was the Imperial family's first Buddhist temple, completed in 639 by Emperor Jomei and, after his death, succeeded by his consort, Empress Kogyoku, and his son, Emperor Tenchi.
This was the Imperial Family's first Buddhist temple, completed in 639 by Emperor Jomei and, after his death, succeeded by his consort, Empress Kogyoku, and his son, Emperor Tenchi.

sen.j: 現在の吉備池廃寺跡に比定されている。
sen.e: It is now identified with the remains of Kibiike disused temple.
It is now identified with the site of Kibiike Abandoned Temple.
It is now identified with the site of Kibiike Abandoned Temple.

sen.j: 完成時には、蘇我氏発願の飛鳥寺を遙かに凌いでいた。
sen.e: When completed, the Kudara-daiji Temple largely surpassed the scale of Asuka-dera Temple that had been built at the wish of Soga clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When completed, Kudara-daiji Temple far surpassed the scale of the Soga Clan's Asuka-dera Temple.
When completed, Kudara-daiji Temple far surpassed the scale of the Soga clan's Asuka-dera Temple.

sen.j: それは、九重の塔がそびえ建ち、高さは法隆寺の五重塔の二倍もあり、現代の25階ビルに相当し、当時の東アジアでも超一級の寺院であった。
sen.e: It was the tip-top temple in the East Asia at that time, with its towering Kujunoto (Nine-story Pagoda) that was two times higher than Gojunoto (Five-story Pagoda) of Horyu-ji Temple, corresponding to current 25 storied building.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It was one of the top temples in East Asia at the time, with its towering nine-story pagoda, equivalent to a modern twenty-five story building, two times higher than Horyu-ji Temple's five-story pagoda.

It was one of the top temples in East Asia at the time, with its towering nine-story pagoda, equivalent to a modern twenty-five story building, two times higher than Horyu-ji Temple's five-story pagoda.

sen.j: 斑鳩寺（法隆寺）
sen.e: Ikuraga-dera Temple (Horyu-ji Temple):
Ikuraga-dera Temple (Horyu-ji Temple)
Ikuraga-dera Temple (Horyu-ji Temple)

sen.j: 聖徳太子の発願による。
sen.e: It was built at the wish of Prince Shotoku.
It was built at the wish of Prince Shotoku.
It was built at the wish of Prince Shotoku.

sen.j: 日本最古の木造建築である。
sen.e: It is the oldest wooden architecture in Japan.
It is the oldest wooden building in Japan.
It is the oldest wooden building in Japan.

sen.j: 秦寺（広隆寺）…秦氏
sen.e: Hata-dera Temple (Koryu-ji Temple) ・・・ Hata clan:
Hata-dera Temple (Koryu-ji Temple) ・・・ Hata Clan
Hata-dera Temple (Koryu-ji Temple)... Hata clan
sen.cmt: 用語統一しました。中黒を変更

sen.j: 渋川廃寺…物部氏（大連守屋）、大阪府八尾市渋川町。
sen.e: Former Shibukawa-ji Temple・・・Mononobe clan (Omuraji Moriya), at Shibukawa-cho, Yao City, Osaka Prefecture
Shibukawa-ji Abandoned Temple・・・Mononobe Clan (Omuraji no Moriya), in Shibukawa-cho, Yao City, Osaka Prefecture
Shibukawa-ji Abandoned Temple... Mononobe clan (Omuraji no Moriya), in Shibukawa-cho, Yao City, Osaka Prefecture
sen.cmt: 用語統一しました。中黒を変更

sen.j: 物部氏も仏教を受容していた。
sen.e: Mononobe clan also took in Buddhism.
The Mononobe clan also became Buddhist.
The Mononobe clan also became Buddhist.

sen.j: 崇仏、排仏論争は蘇我氏が語り伝えたもので、馬子と守屋の政治権力闘争であった。
sen.e: Then dispute on worship or abolishment of Buddhism was just an oral tradition carried down by Soga clan, but there really existed a struggle for political power between SOGA no Umako and MONONOBE no Moriya.

Stories of the disputes over the worship or abolishment of Buddhism were handed down by the Soga Clan, but there really existed a struggle for political power between SOGA no Umako and MONONOBE no Moriya.

Stories of the disputes over the worship or abolishment of Buddhism were handed down by the Soga clan, but there really existed a struggle for political power between SOGA no Umako and MONONOBE no Moriya.

sen.j: 峯岡寺…葛野（かどの、京都市）
sen.e: Mineoka-ji Temple ・・・ Kadono, Kyoto City
Mineoka-ji Temple ・・・ Kadono, Kyoto City
Mineoka-ji Temple... Kadono, Kyoto City

sen.j: 坂田寺…南淵（みなみぶち、明日香村）。
sen.e: Sakata-dera Temple ・・・ Minamibuchi, Asuka-mura
Sakata-dera Temple ・・・ Minamibuchi, Asuka-mura
Sakata-dera Temple... Minamibuchi, Asuka-mura

sen.j: 奈良時代の建物基壇などが発掘されているが、飛鳥時代の遺構は見つかっていない。
sen.e: No structural remnants of the Asuka Period but some stylobates of the Nara Period were found by excavation.
Although some Nara period structural platforms have been excavated, no remnants from the Asuka period have been found.
Although some Nara period structural platforms have been excavated, no remnants from the Asuka period have been found.

sen.j: 豊浦寺（とゆらじ）…蘇我蝦夷
sen.e: Toyura-ji Temple ・・・ SOGA no Emishi
Toyura-ji Temple ・・・ SOGA no Emishi
Toyura-ji Temple... SOGA no Emishi

sen.j: 北魏様式…高句麗経由で伝播。
sen.e: A style of Northern Wei (China) ・・・ Introduced via Koguryo (Gogureo)
Northern Wei style ・・・ Introduced via Goguryeo
Northern Wei style... Introduced via Goguryeo

sen.j: 男性的で端厳、杏仁形の眼、仰月形の鋭い唇、左右対称の幾何学衣文を特徴とする。
sen.e: This style was characterized by its smart and strict figure with eyes in the shape of apricot kernel, lips of sharp crescentic shape and symmetric and geometric patterns on their clothes.
This style was characterized by solemn and majestic masculine figures with apricot kernel-shaped eyes, lips of a sharp crescent shape and symmetric and geometric patterns on their clothes.
This style was characterized by solemn and majestic masculine figures with apricot kernel-shaped eyes, lips of a sharp crescent shape and symmetric and geometric patterns on their clothes.

sen.j: 飛鳥寺釈迦如来像（飛鳥大仏）
sen.e: Shakanyorai zo (a statue of Shakyamuni) at Asuka-ji Temple (also known as Asuka-daibutsu, or a bronze statue of Shakyamuni in a sitting position)
Statue of Shakyamuni at Asuka-ji Temple (also known as the Asuka-daibutsu)
Statue of Shakyamuni at Asuka-ji Temple (also known as the Asuka-daibutsu)

sen.j: - 鞍作止利の作
sen.e: Made by KURATSUKURI no Tori.
Made by KURATSUKURI no Tori.
Made by KURATSUKURI no Tori.

sen.j: 法隆寺金堂釈迦三尊像
sen.e: Shaka Sanzon zo (statues of Shakyamuni triads).at the mainhall of Horyu-ji Temple:
Statues of Shakyamuni triads in Horyu-ji Temple's kondo
Statues of Shakyamuni triads in Horyu-ji Temple's kondo

sen.j: - 鞍作止利の作
sen.e: Made by KURATSUKURI no Tori.
Made by KURATSUKURI no Tori.
Made by KURATSUKURI no Tori.

sen.j: 法隆寺夢殿救世観音像
sen.e: Kuze Kannon zo (a statue of Kuze Kannon) at Yume-dono (the Hall of Dream) of Horyu-ji Temple.
Statue of Kuze Kannon in Horyu-ji Temple's Yume-dono (Hall of Dreams)
Statue of Kuze Kannon in Horyu-ji Temple's Yume-dono (Hall of Dreams)

sen.j: 梁 (南朝)様式（南北朝時代 (中国)様式）…新羅・百済経由で伝播。
sen.e: A style of Ryo (Southern Dynasty) (a style of the period of Northern and Southern dynasties in China)・・・introduced into Japan via Shiragi (Silla) and Kudara (Baekje or Paekche).
Liang style (Southern Dynasty) (a style from the Northern and Southern Dynasties period)・・・introduced into Japan via Silla and Baekje.
Liang style (Southern Dynasty) (a style from the Northern and Southern Dynasties period)・・・introduced into Japan via Silla and Baekje.

sen.j: 長身で丸味があり、変化のある衣の線、アルカイク・スマイルが特徴。
sen.e: This statue is tall and rounded, with a feature of various folds of clothes and archaic smile.
Statues are tall and rounded and features include an archaic smile and clothes with a variety of folds.
Statues are tall and rounded and features include an archaic smile and clothes with a variety of folds.

sen.j: 法隆寺百済観音像
sen.e: Kudara Kannon zo (a statue of Kudara Kannon) at Horyu-ji Temple:
Statue of Kudara Kannon at Horyu-ji Temple
Statue of Kudara Kannon at Horyu-ji Temple

sen.j: 広隆寺弥勒菩薩半跏思惟像
sen.e: Miroku Bosatsu Hanka Shiyui zo (a statue of Miroku Bodhisattva in a sitting position with the left leg pendent, the right leg crossed over the left knee, and the fingers of the right hand lightly touching the cheek), at Koryu-ji Temple:
Miroku Bosatsu Hanka Shiyui statue (Maitreya Bodhisattva sitting contemplatively in the half-lotus position) at Koryu-ji Temple
Miroku Bosatsu Hanka Shiyui statue (Maitreya Bodhisattva sitting contemplatively in the half-lotus position) at Koryu-ji Temple

sen.j: 中宮寺半跏思惟像（弥勒菩薩・寺伝は如意輪観音）
sen.e: Hanka Shiyui zo (a statue in a sitting position with the left leg hanging) (of Miroku Bosatsu, or Nyoirin Kannon according to the temple's record), at Chugu-ji Temple:
Hanka Shiyui statue (possibly of Maitreya Bodhisattva or, according to the temple history, of Nyoirin Kannon) at Chugu-ji Temple
Hanka Shiyui statue (possibly of Maitreya Bodhisattva or, according to the temple history, of Nyoirin Kannon) at Chugu-ji Temple

sen.j: 『三経義疏』（さんぎょうぎしょ）は、仏教に深く傾倒した聖徳太子の著作といわれている。
sen.e: The "Sangyogisho" ("Three Sutra Annotations") is believed to have been written by Prince Shotoku who deeply devoted himself to Buddhism.
The "Sangyogisho" ("Three Sutra Annotations") is believed to have been written by Prince Shotoku who was deeply committed to Buddhism.
The "Sangyogisho" (Three Sutra Annotations) is believed to have been written by Prince Shotoku who was deeply committed to Buddhism.

sen.j: 天寿国曼荼羅繍帳にある「世間虚仮、唯仏是真」（せけんこけ、ゆいぶつぜしん）という言葉は、聖徳太子の晩年の心境をよく窺うことが出来るとされている。
sen.e: He wrote in the Tenjukoku Mandara Shucho a sentence of "Seken Koke Yuibutsu Zeshin" which meant that the real world is false and temporary, only the Buddha is true," from which it is said we can learn how Prince Shotoku was feeling in his later life.
The quote on Tenjukoku Mandara Shucho (a piece of embroidered silk) "the real world is false and temporary, only the Buddha is true" is said to show how Prince Shotoku was feeling in his later life.
The quote on Tenjukoku Mandara Shucho (a piece of embroidered silk) 'the real world is false and temporary, only the Buddha is true' is said to show how Prince Shotoku was feeling in his later life.

sen.j: 天寿国曼荼羅繍帳（てんじゅこくまんだらしゅうちょう）
sen.e: Tenjukoku Mandara Shucho:
Tenjukoku Mandara Shucho
Tenjukoku Mandara Shucho

sen.j: - 中宮寺
sen.e: Chugu-ji Temple
Chugu-ji Temple
Chugu-ji Temple

sen.j: 繍佛（刺繍）、錦などの染織品が伝世している。
sen.e: Embroideries, brocades and other dyed or woven fabric works of Buddhist images have been transferred from generation to generation.
Embroideries, brocades and other dyed or woven fabric works of Buddhist images have been handed down from generation to generation.
Embroideries, brocades and other dyed or woven fabric works of Buddhist images have been handed down from generation to generation.

sen.j: 飛鳥各地に存在する猿石・道祖神石、橘寺の二面石などと呼ばれる石造物、宗教の遺物と考えられている。
sen.e: Everywhere in Asuka area, there can be found many stone structural objects such as Saruishi (Monkey stones), stones of Doso-jin (travelers' guardian deity) and nimen-ishi (a double faced stone) at Tachibana-dera Temple, which are all considered as religious relics.

Throughout the Asuka area, there can be found many stone objects such as the Saruishi (Monkey Stones), Doso-jin (travelers' guardian deity) carved form stone and Tachibana-dera Temple's Nimen-ishi (Double-faced Stone), all of which are considered religious relics.

Throughout the Asuka area, there can be found many stone objects such as the Saruishi (Monkey Stones), Doso-jin (travelers' guardian deity) carved form stone and Tachibana-dera Temple's Nimen-ishi (Double-faced Stone), all of which are considered religious relics.

tit.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 百済の僧、観勒（かんろく）が暦本と天文・地理の書を献じた。
sen.e: Kanroku, a monk from Kudara (Baekje or Paekche), made a present of calendars and books of astronomy and geography.
Gwalleuk (or Kanroku in Japanese), a monk from Baekje, presented calendars and books of astronomy and geography.
Gwalleuk (or Kanroku in Japanese), a monk from Baekje, presented calendars and books of astronomy and geography.

sen.j: 高句麗の僧、曇徴（どんちょう）が絵具や紙・墨を作る方法を伝えた。
sen.e: Doncho, a monk from Koguryo (Goguryeo), introduced techniques to produce paints, paper and sumi (chinese ink).
Damjing (or Doncho in Japanese), a monk from Goguryeo, introduced methods for producing paint, paper and sumi (Chinese ink).
Damjing (or Doncho in Japanese), a monk from Goguryeo, introduced methods for producing paint, paper and sumi (Chinese ink).

tit.cmt: 文頭のみ大文字にしました。

sen.j: 豊浦宮
sen.e: Toyura no Miya Imperial Residence (Imperial Palace of Toyura):
Toyura no Miya Palace
Toyura no Miya Palace

sen.j: - 蘇我氏の氏寺であった豊浦寺を改修して宮とした。
sen.e: Toyura-dera Temple that was an Uji-dera temple of Soga clan (a temple built for praying glory of Soga clan) was remade into this palace,.
Toyura-dera Temple, an uji-dera (clan temple) of the Soga Clan was remade into this palace,.
Toyura-dera Temple, an uji-dera (clan temple) of the Soga clan was remade into this palace,.

sen.j: 推古天皇
sen.e: Emperor Suiko
Empress Suiko
Empress Suiko

sen.j: 小墾田宮‎
sen.e: Oharida no Miya Imperial Residence (Oharida Palace):
Oharida no Miya Palace
Oharida no Miya Palace

sen.j: - 後の宮殿の原型となる。
sen.e: This palace became a prototype of subsequent palaces.
This palace became a prototype of subsequent palaces.
This palace became a prototype of subsequent palaces.

sen.j: 603年、推古天皇遷る。
sen.e: In 603, Emperor Suiko moved to this palace.
In 603, Empress Suiko moved to this palace.
In 603, Empress Suiko moved to this palace.

sen.j: 飛鳥板葺宮
sen.e: Asuka Itabuki no Miya Palace:
Asuka Itabuki no Miya Palace
Asuka Itabuki no Miya Palace

sen.j: - 643年、皇極天皇即位 645年、大化の改新
sen.e: In 643, Empress Kogyoku ascended the throne, and in 645, Taika no Kaishin (the Great Reformation of Taika Era) began.
In 643, Empress Kogyoku ascended the throne, and in 645, the Taika Reforms began.
In 643, Empress Kogyoku ascended the throne, and in 645, the Taika Reforms began.

sen.j: 後飛鳥岡本宮
sen.e: Nochino Asuka Okamoto no Miya Imperial Residence:
Later Asuka Okamoto no Miya Palace
Later Asuka Okamoto no Miya Palace

sen.j: 壬申の乱の直後に天武天皇遷宮
sen.e: Immediately after the Jinshin War, Emperor Tenmu moved his residence.
Immediately after the Jinshin War, Emperor Tenmu moved his residence here.
Immediately after the Jinshin War, Emperor Tenmu moved his residence here.

sen.j: 飛鳥浄御原宮
sen.e: Asuka Kiyomigahara no Miya Imperial Residence:
Asuka Kiyomigahara no Miya Palace
Asuka Kiyomigahara no Miya Palace

sen.j: 内郭・外郭を持ち,内郭が北・南区画に分かれている。
sen.e: This palace consisted of uchiguruwa (inner compound) and sotoguruwa (outer compound), and the inner compound was further divided into North and South compartments.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This palace consisted of an inner compound and an outer compound, with the inner compound further divided into northern and southern sections.
This palace consisted of an inner compound and an outer compound, with the inner compound further divided into northern and southern sections.

sen.j: 北区画に宮殿、南区に朝堂と南門を持つ。
sen.e: The palace was located in the North compartment, and the chodo (the Imperial court) and the south gate stood in the South compartment.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The main palace building was located in the northern section, and the chodo (Imperial Court Hall) and the South Gate stood in the southern section.
The main palace building was located in the northern section, and the chodo (Imperial Court Hall) and the South Gate stood in the southern section.
